goals: To comprehend African American literature and culture via reading Toni Morrison’s work.
To study how Toni Morrison’s literary imagination brings to life important aspects of American reality.
To enhance students’ ability to read and analyze fiction.
To understand the circulation/reception of Toni Morrison’s work and assess her legacies.
syllabus:
**Seminar on Toni Morrison**

**Spring 2022** 

Time: Mondays 2:20 - 5:30 p.m.

Classroom: TBA

Instructor: Prof. Hsiu-chuan Lee (李秀娟)

Office: 英語系 誠722

Office hours: Monday 12-2 p.m.; Wed 1-3 p.m., or by appointment

E-mail: [hclee@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:hclee@ntnu.edu.tw)

Course Description:

This seminar takes a single author—the US Nobel laureate Toni Morrison (1931-2019)—as the focus of studies. Students will be introduced to Morrison as one of the greatest contemporary creative writers who told unforgettable stories with global reach, and also as an influential intellectual and literary/cultural critic who sharply engaged with topics as wide-ranging as race, gender, class, histories, languages, and humanity/human relationships in general. Highlighted among the readings for Spring 2022 are Morrison’s first novel _The Bluest Eye_ (1970), her last novel _God Help the Child_ (2015), the Pulitzer Prize-winning _Beloved_ (1987; also chosen by _The New York Times_ as the best work of American fiction from 1981 to 2006), and the lesser-known (yet richly textualized) _Tar Baby_ (1981). We will also read the short story “Racitatif’ (1983), the play _Desdemona_ (2012), texts selected from Morrison’s essay collections and some of the most updated research essays on Morrison and her work. In addition to written texts we will view _Toni Morrison: The Pieces I Am_(2019)—a documentary released a few months before Morrison passed away to examine the author’s life, work, major themes and impacts—and clips from the film adaptation of _Beloved_ (1998). Overall, this seminar aims to disclose the richness of Morrison’s oeuvre, probe into the depth and breadth of her thoughts and creativity, and investigate her influences on the global reading and writing of literature. Given the inclusiveness and open-ended nature of this seminar, students are encouraged to close-read Morrison’s writings and explore them from whichever perspective that is of interest. 

Grading:

1.  Attendance and participation (25%)
2.  Oral presentation(s) and leading discussions (20%): 2 times, one leading discussion of a fictional text, and one oral presentation on non-fiction texts
3.  Weekly one paragraph responses/questions to reading materials on MOODLE (25%): at least 8 responses through the semester; please upload your paragraph unto MOODLE no later than one day prior to the class meeting
4.  Final Paper (30%)

**Required Texts:**

Students are required to prepare their own copies of the four novels: _The Bluest Eye_, _Tar Baby_, _Beloved_, and _God Help the Child_ (all editions are acceptable, but Vintage International editions are recommended for those who plan to order new copies).
